description.hltext_display: Lake Worth Clinic Robbery Caught On Camera
description.content:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office said Tuesday that a man suspected of robbing a Lake Worth pain clinic has been arrested after a four-hour standoff at the Congress Park apartments.
On Tuesday, deputies released video of the incident.
Sheriff Ric Bradshaw said the man, identified as Jeffrey Frederick, returned to the pain clinic brandishing a gun after doctors refused to give him drugs.
A doctor tried to disarm him at the entrance, but Frederick won in the struggle, deputies said.
As the female employees took cover, Frederick was able to take an unspecified amount of cash from the register, Bradshaw said.
Deputies said Frederick fled from the clinic to a nearby mobile home park, where they said he escaped in a waiting car driven by Friendly Sertile.
Frederick and Sertile then drove to the Congress Park apartment where they holed themselves up for four hours before a SWAT team convinced the pair to surrender, Bradshaw said.
Both Frederick and Sertile were arrested, deputies said.
Previous Stories: December 21, 2010:

description.hltext_display: 1 Shot In Belle Glade Attack
description.content:
Victim Flown To Delray Medical Center
UPDATED: 10:28 pm EST December 21, 2010
Email Print
BELLE GLADE, Fla. -- Palm Beach County deputies are investigating a shooting that happened in Belle Glade.
Investigators said the shooting happened at about 9:45 p.m. Tuesday in the 400 block of Southwest Third Street.
Deputies said the victim was shot in the torso while walking down the street. The victim was flown to Delray Medical Center.
No arrests have been reported.
Officials have not released the victim's name or condition.

description.hltext_display: Troops Return Home In Time For Holidays
description.content:
Embed this Video
Facebook
Digg
Twitter
Yahoo Buzz
Reddit
Delicious
Link
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- After nearly a year away from home, Sgt. 1st Class Matthew Newman arrived in West Palm Beach just in time for the holidays.
He was greeted by family and friends.
"Well, I wasn't expecting it, to be honest with you. I was trying to keep it hidden," Newman said.
Newman lives in The Acreage and is a member of the 53rd Infantry Brigade Combat Team.
The Florida National Guard unit arrived in Fort Stewart, Ga., last week, officials said.
The "Gator Brigade," as it's called, spent the deployment in Iraq and Kuwait, helping with security and logistics operations.
"If you picture Interstate 95 with things that could explode on the side of the road everywhere, it gets a little bit more specific than that," Newman said.
Newman said he looks forward to relaxing and spending time with his wife, family and friends.
However, he won't be out of uniform for long.
He said he plans to return to work soon as a deputy with the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office.

description.hltext_display: Madoff Associate Turns Self In After Bail Revoked
description.content:
Former Secretary Has Been Under House Arrest In Boca Raton
UPDATED: 5:23 pm EST December 21, 2010
Email Print
Bongiorno Turns Self In At Federal Courthouse
Embed this Video
Facebook
Digg
Twitter
Yahoo Buzz
Reddit
Delicious
Link
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- A former secretary for disgraced financier Bernie Madoff turned herself in at the federal courthouse Tuesday, minutes before her 3 p.m. deadline.
Annette Bongiorno was ordered to return to jail after a New York judge revoked her bail. She had been under house arrest in Boca Raton but had trouble making her $5 million bail.
Bongiorno was arrested last month on conspiracy and securities fraud charges. She is accused of helping Madoff dupe investors, making her wealthy.
Prosecutors have argued the 62-year-old has the means to flee because she has stashed away millions in stolen investor money.
Accompanied by her husband, Bongiorno had nothing to say as she walked through the throng of media outside the courthouse.
"Don't touch her with that camera, I'm telling you right now," Bongiorno's husband said.
Bongiorno's surrender means she'll now spend Christmas in confinement in South Florida before being transferred to New York to await trial.
The U.S. marshal in charge of her transfer said she won't receive any special treatment.
"She won't fly commercial," Wayne Pickering said. "She'll be flying in what everyone commonly refers to as Con Air. She'll fly like everybody else flies. No special treatment."
Previous Stories:
November 25, 2010: Madoff Associate Released On Bail, Placed On House Arrest
November 22, 2010: Madoff Associate To Remain In Jail For Now
November 18, 2010: Madoff Associate To Spend Weekend In Jail After Arrest

description.hltext_display: Gdzie się podziały rzeźby lodowe?
description.content:
- Co się stało? Ktoś je zniszczył? - dopytują ludzie przechodzący Starym Rynkiem. Jeszcze w niedzielę tłumy fotografowały się na tle misternie rzeźbionych lodowych sań, syren, roślin. We wtorek od rana rzeźby były w kawałkach.
- To my je usunęliśmy, zaczęły się topić i nie wyglądały już atrakcyjnie. To z założenia była wystawa czasowa. I tak długo postały - tłumaczy Karolina Walkowiak z poznańskiego magistratu. Po południu nie było już po nich śladu.
Cuda z lodu stworzone przez uczestników Międzynarodowego Festiwalu Rzeźby Lodowej stały na rynku przez tydzień.

description.hltext_display: Vikings coach won't put Favre on IR list
description.content:
EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — In the wake of two embarrassingly lopsided losses, interim coach Leslie Frazier isn't giving up on Brett Favre and the Minnesota Vikings.
Frazier said he would not put Favre on season-ending injured reserve with a concussion and wouldn't rule out a return to the field before the season is over.
"He's proven time and time again that he's capable of coming back and playing," Frazier said Tuesday.
Favre made a surprise start against Chicago on Monday night after being ruled out on Saturday with a sprained right throwing shoulder. He threw for 63 yards with one touchdown and an interception before getting knocked out of the game in the second quarter on a sack by Bears defensive end Corey Wootton.
Frazier said it was unlikely the 41-year-old quarterback could recover from the concussion in time to play Sunday at Philadelphia, but wouldn't rule out a return for the season finale at Detroit on Jan. 2.
Favre has said several times this will be his last season, and Frazier said the veteran doesn't want to go out watching from the bench.
"He doesn't want to let his teammates down," Frazier said. "He really wanted to play in front of the home fans last night for maybe the last time. That was important to him. I think more than anything he likes to compete and the fact that we've got two ballgames left, he's a guy who loves his teammates and loves to play. I think that's what motivates him more than anything."
If Favre cannot play, rookie Joe Webb will be the starter with recently signed veteran Patrick Ramsey as the backup. The Vikings were also considering signing Rhett Bomar off the Giants practice squad as insurance.
